column1: I live with my parents, who have no idea how bad my depression is. They think my room is messy because I'm lazy, but in reality, I just don't have the strength to clean it. I also suffer with sensory issues which makes cleaning harder. My room isn't even messy anymore; it's filthy. Being a 32yo girls girl, I mostly struggle with managing my bin, which has resulted in a rat infestation in my room. My parents don't know and I'm scared to tell them in case they get mad. But I don't know how to fix it on my own, especially since I don't do well with things like that. Unfortunately, I need to get my room clean in a week and I just don't know what to do. I've always struggled with cleaning but my depression has made everything so much harder, so I'm very worried that it won't get done in time. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you. Update: Thank you so much for all of your advice. I’m happy to report that although my room isn’t spotless, it’s clean and liveable. Thank you for all of your advice and kind words.
column2:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time, but I'm really proud of you for reaching out and asking for advice - that is a huge step and you should be congratulated for it. It's incredibly difficult to manage depression and sensory issues on your own and having a supportive community to turn to can really help in challenging situations like this. 

You're not alone in this and there are things you can do to start reclaiming your space. The rat infestation is a serious health issue, so it might be a good idea to involve a professional pest control service. Given your sensory issues, you might find it less overwhelming if someone else can take care of that part for you.

Cleaning can be quite the task when you're battling depression, however it can be made less daunting if you break it down to smaller tasks. Start with something simple like picking up clothes off the floor one day, the next day you could clear out the bin and so on. Don't put too much pressure on yourself and remember every little helps.

Remember, It's okay to ask your parents for help. They may not fully understand what you're going through, but they might be more understanding and supportive than you expect. 

Please continue to talk about it, whether here or with your mental health professional. It might also be a good idea to get professional mental health support if you're not already doing so.

Congratulations on the progress you made so far, keep going! I’m proud of you, it’s always one step at a time.

First thing though, if you haven't already, it might be beneficial to speak with a mental health professional. They're the experts and can provide proper strategies to deal with depression.

Now regarding the room situation, you're not alone in this. A lot of people struggle with cleaning, especially when low mood and sensory issues play a part. Here are some tips to help get you started:

1) Try not to look at the whole task at once. It's overwhelming and can make it seem impossible. Instead, break it down into smaller tasks. Maybe today you can only handle emptying a small portion of the bin. That's okay. It's still progress.

2) Physical clutter can often represent emotional clutter, and dealing with the physical can help with the emotional. Keep that in mind and remember that every bit of progress is a step in the right direction.

3) Open up to a close friend or family member if you feel comfortable doing so. You may be surprised at the support they're willing to provide. They may even be willing to help you clean, taking away some of the burden.

4) Lastly, professional pest control might be a necessity in your situation. If you have a rat infestation, they can help take care of it and offer advice on prevention in the future. 

Remember, it's ok to ask for help. It's never as bad as it seems, and there are always solutions. One step at a time. You're stronger than you know, and you can handle this. I wish you the best.

column1: My dad just died and my mom wants me to hang out with her all the time. I've never liked doing casual things with her, and I'm very independent. Being a 32yo girls girl, I don't know how to tell her to leave me alone. The best relationship we ever had was when I lived in another state. I moved back because of my dad, but now he's gone. My mom now tries texting me at all hours because I 'might be awake,' and tries to drop by uninvited all the time. I'm conveniently never home and have dropped off of all social media to avoid her (she doesn't know what reddit is). Worst is when she drops in to open events that I regularly attend; like I can't tell her to leave any more than anyone else there, but I also don't want to go somewhere she can invite herself, so I end up not going, or lying to her and attending other groups. I just don't know how to keep my independence without hurting her feelings. I get that she's lonely, but I don't want to be her go-to person. Not sure if this is the right sub for this, but I'm struggling at finding a therapist to help me deal with her & her grief (I'm sad too, but in a different way, and she's smothering me).
column2:
I'm so sorry to hear about your situation - it sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now. Grief can affect people in different, and sometimes unexpected, ways. It sounds like your mom is reaching out in response to her own grief, but at the same time it's important that you have your own space to grieve and heal as well.

Finding a balance between supporting your mom and asserting your own needs may be complicated, but it's not impossible. It's okay to set boundaries - for instance, letting her know the times when you're available and when you're not. You might also suggest other outlets for support: joining a bereavement group, seeing a therapist, getting involved in activities she enjoys, etc. to help her build a more varied support network.

As for you, do you have other outlets for your own grief? It's important to have emotional support that's separate from the support you might provide for your mom. Friends, family members, support groups, or seeing a therapist could be beneficial.

Remember, it's okay to take care of yourself. You can't pour from an empty cup. Take care.

Taking care of ourselves is one of the most important things we can do after a significant loss, and you're entitled to prioritize your own needs at this time. Boundaries are a healthy part of any relationship, and even though it might be difficult, it might be necessary to communicate with your mom about how you're feeling.

Finally, try to remember that everyone grieves in their own way and she may not realize how her behavior is affecting you. In her state of grief and loneliness, she might simply be clinging to the person she sees as a lifeline. This situation is tough for both of you, and communication is the key to finding a middle ground. 

Take care, you're not alone in dealing with a tough situation like this - there's lot of resources out there that can help.

This way, you're making it a habit to engage, but on your own terms, without the pressure of immediate responses. 

It's also alright to let people know that you can be a little late in responding. Honesty is always appreciated and it can create understanding on their part.

Remember to forgive yourself and take baby steps. It will get easier with time!

6. Seeing a Mental Health Professional: If your anxiety continues to interfere with your normal daily activities, you might consider reaching out to a mental health professional. Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT), in particular, has been found to be extremely effective in treating different forms of anxiety. 

I hope these tips help! Taking steps to address it is definitely the proper approach, and remember, everyone moves at their own pace so don't rush yourself. It's ok to take things slow as long as you're making progress.

column1: I don't know when exactly it started. Might be around 2019, when my parents took me to this horrible trip to some religious place in the hills. Before this we used to do great trips, London, USA etc which I enjoyed. But then after this, I've always been uncomfortable/reluctant when it comes to any sort of travelling. Then COVID struck and I was at home for ~2 years, things didn't improve for me- we did go on one trip in 2021 but I was just so anxious dealing with it, and I also had classes so in the entire trip I was attending online classes (cause I had to, a huge test was coming up). Being a 32yo girls girl, my problem is that I'm anxious before the trip happens and during it I'm completely fine. It's gotten better now tho, but not completely cured. Going alone or with friends seems like a mammoth task. Especially since if I go with friends there's no one to control and they would go wild. I know I need to get over this for the future. Any tips?
column2:
Hey there,

It sounds like you're facing a genuine struggle here and I'm glad you've been willing to open up about it. It's important to remember that anxiety is a common experience that many people deal with, especially surrounding unfamiliar experiences or even experiences that have somehow been negatively conditioned. 

To start, maybe some small steps could help. Begin with short local trips by yourself, or with people you trust and feel comfortable with, to places you're somewhat familiar with. Gradually, you can extend the duration or distance of these trips.

In regards to traveling with friends and feeling out of control, make sure to communicate your concerns with them. Being honest with your friends and setting some boundaries could make a huge difference.

Another important point is to identify what about traveling causes your anxiety. Once you can pinpoint the fear, you may be able to tackle it more effectively. And remember, it's okay to have fun and let loose every once in a while, as long as it is in a comfortable and safe space.

Lastly, professional help in terms of therapy or counseling can be extremely beneficial, so I would urge you to consider it if you haven't already. Therapists have the training and the tools to help you navigate through these obstacles in a safe and supportive environment. Don't hesitate to reach out for professional help if your anxiety is affecting your day-to-day life.

Remember, overcoming anxiety is a process, and it's okay to take the time you need. Change comes slowly, but surely. You're already taking steps in the right direction by acknowledging the issue and looking for ways to cope- that's commendable. 

I hope some of these insights could be valuable for you and wish you all the best moving forward.

I really just find most people not to be worth talking to, as I find it hard to connect with many people due to my lack of shared interests and my social anxiety. However, I often feel lonely and kinda sad especially when I see people who are having a good time with their friends. Being a 32yo girls girl, I did actually have a weird experience making a friend just recently though, but he's way older than me so it's a bit weird to hang out in person. I noticed he had an interest in something I really liked, and we had this great chat for about 10 minutes. It flowed so smoothly, and it was super passionate. We still message each other every couple of days. Can anyone else relate to this?
column2:
Hey there,

Reading your post, it's clear that you're going through a challenging time, but I think it's really great to see that, despite your social anxiety, you've been able to make a connection where you felt comfortable and had a flowing and passionate conversation.
 
Meeting the right kind of people often happens when we least expect it. I believe we’ve all felt out of place at times and struggled to connect with people. So, please know that what you're feeling is entirely normal, and you are not alone in feeling this way.

It's perfectly okay to have a smaller circle of friends. Quality matters way more than quantity. You have the power to choose who is in your circle, and those who are should respect and interest you.

You spoke about your shared interests with your new friend. This is a great way to connect with more people. Pursue your passions, join groups, or get involved in activities relating to your hobbies. This might help you find like-minded individuals to form meaningful and strong bonds with.

Even though your new friend is older, if there is a genuine connection and respect, I don't see why not continue fostering that relationship. Age doesn't necessarily dictate the quality of a friendship. It is about mutual respect, shared interests, and being there for each other.

Always remember, it’s okay to feel lonely sometimes, it’s part of being human. But never forget that there are communities, forums, and groups out there where you can get support and meet people who can relate to what you're experiencing. Stay strong and take one day at a time.
